text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

Audience: Revised to indicate the transfer of the Compliance Review of the Form 8038-CP from Government Entities Compliance Services to Compliance Planning & Classiﬁcation, Field Assistance Support Team.
IRM 4.8.12.1.3(1): Responsibilities changed to indicate that CP&C (formerly ITG/TEB) is responsible for the administration, procedures and policies contained in this IRM.
IRM 4.8.12.1.3(1): Added statement to indicate that ITG/TEB will be consulted prior to making changes to the procedures contained in this IRM.
IRM 4.81.12.1.4: Deleted the Program reports subsection.
IRM 4.81.12.2.1: Deleted TCO from this section and added FAST where applicable.
IRM 4.81.12.2.1(6): Added Recipient to identify which document needs to be saved and removed listing since no long applicable.
IRM 4.81.12.2.1(9)a: Deleted the reference to a listing since no longer applicable. The list is printed on the Form 3210.
IRM 4.81.12.2.3.1: Deleted TCO, revised and added the instructions for establishing Form 8038-CP in RCCMS. Deleted the codes used in RCCMS for referring the form to ITG/TEB Tech 2.
IRM 4.81.12.3: Removed GECU and added FAST. Removed TCO and clariﬁed
IRM 4.81.12.3.1(4): Added information for editing the Form 8038-CP,
IRM 4.81.12.3.1(5): Replaced GECU with FAST, added Duplicate for the top left-margin edits. Added reference (in Note) to Letter 4617-C and Letter 5836-C used by ERS/Rejects for return that is
4.81.12.3.2: Added section to provide instructions for Early-Filed Forms
4.81.12.3.7(3): Added instructions when the TE reaches the taxpayer for missing IPD.
4.81.12.3.7.2 Part 1, Line 1: Previously numbered as subsection 4.81.12.3.6.2.
IRM 4.81.12.3.7.6 Line 10: Report Number and Duplicate Return Check deleted Duplicate Return Check. Previously listed as IRM 4.81.12.3.6.6 Line 10, Report Number.
IRM 4.81.12.3.7.10 Part III, Line 18: Previously listed as IRM 4.81.12.3.6.9; revised information on establishing the Form 8038-CP in RCCMS. Updated table to clarify payment frequency information.
IRM 4.81.12.3.7.11: Part III, Lines 20a, 20b, and 20e: Previously listed as IRM 4.81.12.3.6.10. Added BABs, RZEDBs, and NCREBs, QECBs, QZABs and QSCBs to the title.
IRM 4.81.12.3.7.11: Part III, Lines 20a, 20b, and 20e: Previously listed as IRM 4.81.12.3.6.10. Added BABs, RZEDBs, and NCREBs, QECBs, QZABs and QSCBs to the title.
IRM 4.81.12.3.7.11: Revised the table for procedures on establishing the Form 8038-CP in RCCMS and added the line numbers associated with the bonds from Form 8038-CP.
4.81.12.3.7.12.2: Removed the duplicate information in the table for occasions when line 22 is

IRM 4.81.12.3.7.13., Part III, Line 23: Previously numbered as IRM 4.81.12.3.6.12. Revised table on the procedures for establishing the Form 8038-CP in RCCMS.
IRM 4.81.12.3.9 Disallowed Returns: Previously numbered as IRM 4.81.12.3.8. Added instructions to annotate the database for returns processed as a No Consideration.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This supersedes IRM 4.81.12 dated September 26, 2018.

The refundable credits are: a. Payable to the issuer of qualiﬁed obligations, or at the issuer’s option, the designated person who pays interest on behalf of the issuer. b. Based on a percentage (from
to

percent) of the interest under the obligation. c. Designed to lower the issuer’s cost of borrowing as a replacement of federal tax beneﬁt provided to bondholders by traditional tax-exempt bonds under IRC
d. These qualiﬁed obligations are collectively known as direct pay • Build America bonds • Recovery zone economic development bonds • Speciﬁed tax credit bonds (
) Due to the potential for fraud, TEGE, in cooperation with the Wage and ment (W&I) operating division, established a compliance review of all Form
-CP returns during their initial processing. This review is done in two parts: a. CP&C reviews the return for conformity with ITG/TEB records of the direct pay bonds transaction.
Authority: Direct Pay Bonds (DPBs) are obligations that meet applicable re- quirements for credits allowed under IRC 6431.
Note: The credit on DPBs is treated as an overpayment of tax and under IRC
(b) is to be paid (contemporaneously with each interest payment date under such bonds) to the Issuer of such bonds (or to any person who makes interest payments on behalf of the Issuer). IRC
was repealed by section
(b) of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of
, P.L.
Stat.
), effective for bonds issued after December
State and local governments, and other qualiﬁed issuers of DPBs use Form 8038-CP, Return for Credit Payments to Issuers of Qualiﬁed Bonds, to claim:
Payable to the issuer of qualiﬁed obligations, or at the issuer’s option, to the designated person who pays interest on behalf of the issuer. Based on a percentage (from
to

percent) of the interest payable under the obligation. Designed to lower the issuer’s cost of borrowing as a replacement of the federal tax beneﬁt provided to bondholders by traditional tax-exempt bonds under IRC
These qualiﬁed obligations are collectively known as direct pay bonds:

Carryforward must be used within two calendar years. Thus, no direct pay QZABs could be issued after December 31, 2012.

Compliance Review of Form 8038-CP 4.81.12

Type of Bond Statute/Authority DPBs and tax credit bonds The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (P.L. 115-97) repealed the authority to issue tax credit bonds, including speciﬁed tax credit bonds. The repeal applies to qualiﬁed forestry conservation bonds, new clean renewable energy bonds, qualiﬁed energy conservation bonds, qualiﬁed zone academy bonds, and qualiﬁed school con- struction bonds issued after December 31, 2017. The authority to issue recovery zone economic development bonds and build America bonds expired on January 1, 2011. See special rule for QZABs above.

(1) A return isn’t considered ﬁled for interest computation purposes until the return is received in processable form. (2) A return in processable form: Date (IPD) • Is ﬁled on a permitted form. • Contains the taxpayer’s name, address, and identifying number. • Has the required signature(s); and contains sufficient information (whether on the return or on required attachments) to permit the math- ematical veriﬁcation of the tax credit shown on the return. (3) The TE attempts to call the taxpayer for the missing interest payment date (IPD). (4) TE is able to reach the taxpayer. a. Edit the return to show the IPD. b. If applicable, edit the Correspondence Received Date (CRD) in the lower left-hand corner of the return in YYYYMMDD format. Refer to IRM 3.12. 38.5.2.7(7) Correspondence Received Date (CRD)-8 to determine if the CRD is applicable. c. Continue the review process and add it to a batch. (5) TE is unable to reach the taxpayer: Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No. 55322V (10-01-2019)

) Add edit marks to the return (such as IPD, RPT Number, and EIN) for tran- scribing into the ADP system through the Integrated Submission and Remittance Processing (ISRP) system. Note: It’s essential to properly edit Form
-CP to ensure the returns ﬂow smoothly through the submission processing pipeline. (
) FAST employees use green pencil/pen to make edit marks. Note: A green gel pen is more legible on scanned copies. (
) Never destroy, alter or erase the original entry on a return when deleting or correcting an entry. Make sure the original entry remains legible. Perfected entries create a legible “audit trail.” (
) See IRM

process the return except for any missing Interest Payment (IPD). For certain math errors or missing information, ERS/ Rejects will either correct the math error or issue Letter
-C requesting missing or incomplete information from the ﬁler. If ﬁler doesn’t provide the requested information, ERS/Rejects processes the claim as a “No Consideration” return and sends Letter
-C to the taxpayer. FAST’s role is limited to:
) ensuring the return has enough mation to generate a unique report number;
) Calling the for missing IPD, entity information on lines
and

to generate a unique report number to affix to the return and com- pleting a compliance review of the return to minimize the risk of paying refunds on non-qualifying claims. FAST may assist with Unpostables or ERS/Rejects, but that isn’t part of the initial processing.

provide the procedural rules for claiming the re- fundable credit available under IRC
, including the requirement that an issuer must ﬁle a Form
-CP to claim the credit. The due date with respect to variable rate bonds is the
th day after the last interest payment within the quarterly period for which the credit is claimed. For ﬁxed rate bonds, the due date is the
th day before the applicable interest payment date. (

and
on the Form
-CP. Each return should reﬂect credit for a separate DPB transaction, or a portion of that transaction. Examples include:

a. Trustee banks are often designated to receive DPB’s credit payments on behalf of the issuer. As the designated payee, the bank EIN issued to process returns for many different customers paying interest on the same interest payment date. b. An issuer of DPB’s may have two or more obligations that pay interest on the same date. Additionally, one DPB issue may have ﬁxed-rate and variable-rate bonds, or regular BABs (
percent credit rate) and Recovery Zone Economic Development Bonds (RZEDBs) at a
percent credit rate included in the same issue.

These circumstances require the issuer to ﬁle separate returns using the same payee EIN and same interest payment date. To distinguish bond returns using the same EIN and period, a report number is assigned to each return.

Using the DPB Database, enter the payee’s EIN, issuer’s EIN and tax period (in other words, the year and month of the IPD is used to determine the tax period). After you’ve entered the issuer’s EIN into database, the database will search all records for returns using the payee’s EIN for the tax period entered. and

series of report numbers as needed. The report number ﬁeld is only generated through this automated process to ensure that the payee’s EIN, tax period, and report are unique for each return and for the record in the database. The Payee’s EIN, CP period, report number, or issuer’s EIN can’t be changed.

Payments on bonds can be made at different frequencies: monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, and annually. Check the IPD against the payment frequency shown on the Approved Transaction tab in the DPB database.
